history.content: EDIT: I just realized that you're actually confusing inverse with opposite. The inverse of $$\omega_n^2$$ is $$\omega_n^{n - 2}$$ because $$\omega_n^2 \cdot \omega_n^{n - 2} = \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} 2\big) \cdot \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} (n - 2)\big) = \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} n\big) = 1$$.  But, the opposite of $$\omega_n^2$$ is $$\omega_n^{\frac{n}{2} + 2}$$, i.e. $$\omega_n^2 = -\omega_n^{\frac{n}{2} + 2}$$ because $$-1 \cdot \omega_n^2 = (1, \pi) \cdot \big(1, \frac{4 \pi}{n}\big) = \big(1, \frac{(4+n) \pi}{n}\big) = \omega_n^{\frac{n}{2} + 2}$$. Hope this helps.

EDIT: I just realized that you're actually confusing inverse with opposite. The inverse of $$\omega_n^2$$ is $$\omega_n^{n - 2}$$ because $$\omega_n^2 \cdot \omega_n^{n - 2} = \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} 2\big) \cdot \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} (n - 2)\big) = \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} n\big) = 1$$.  But, the opposite of $$\omega_n^2$$ is $$\omega_n^{\frac{n}{2} + 2}$$, i.e. $$\omega_n^2 = -\omega_n^{\frac{n}{2} + 2}$$. Hope this helps.

Here's how I look at it: If we look at the complex plane, for $$\omega_n$$, we're dividing the unit circle into $$n$$ equal slices. With $$\omega_n^2$$, you have two slices, and so you need $$n - 2$$ more slices to return to $$1 = (1, 2 \pi j)$$, for some number $$j$$. You can check that this is true: $$\omega_n^2 \cdot \omega_n^{n - 2} = \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} 2\big) \cdot \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} (n - 2)\big) = \big(1, \frac{2\pi}{n} n\big) = 1$$.

I'm not sure what $$\omega_n^{\frac{n}{2} + 2}$$ would answer. For example, if $$n = 16$$, then $$\omega_n^{\frac{n}{2} + 2} = \omega_{16}^{10}$$, which when multiplied by $$\omega_{16}^2$$ won't get us to $$1$$.

children.subject:
When multiplying a quantity by its inverse the product is 1.  On a unit circle the inverse is the reflection about the real (horizontal) axis.  You can work through a couple examples to demonstrate this to yourself.  In fact I had to do this during the exam to prove it to myself because I was questioning my memory.

Think about the 4th roots of unity.

$${\omega _{4}}^{0} = 1 + 0i$$ points to the right on the unit circle.  Its inverse is the reflection about the real axis... i.e. itself.  $$1\cdot 1 = 1$$

$${\omega _{4}}^{1} = 0 + i$$ points up on the unit circle.  Its inverse is the reflection about the real axis.  $$-i\cdot i = -i^{2} = 1$$

$${\omega _{4}}^{2} = -1 + 0i$$ points to the left on the unit circle.  Its inverse is the reflection about the real axis... i.e. itself.  $$-1\cdot -1 = 1$$

$${\omega _{4}}^{3} = 0 - i$$ points down on the unit circle.  Its inverse is the reflection about the real axis.  $$-i\cdot i = -i^{2} = 1$$
Omg yes you're right! Thank you!!!!!!!!

history.content:
Have been reviewing the exam and understand most of it now except one part. Can someone please help me understand why the inverse of wn^2 written as = ωn^j is j = n-2?  Why is it not j = n/2 + 2? I rewatched the vid and still dont understand.

I know we are far ahead of this topic now, but I'm afraid it will come back to haunt me on the final! :)

Thanks!
history.subject: Roots of Unity Inverse
